msg.data:
About

Lab: Writing, Configuring, and Running a Spark Application
Objective: Write your own Spark application instead of usng the interactive Spark shell application.
File locations:

Hive Tables: devsh.accounts
Scala project: $DEVSH/exercises/spark-application/accounts-by-state_project
Scala classes: stubs.AccountsByState
               solution.AccountsByState
Python stub: accounts-by-state.py

Successful outcome:
Before you begin:
Related lessons:

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Setup

The Spark application will take a single argument -- a state code (such as `CA`). The program should read the data from the telco.accounts Hive table and save the rows whose state column value matches the specified state code. Write the results to `/user/zeppelin/accounts_by_state/`*state-code* (such as `accounts_by_state/CA`).

msg.data:
Setup

The Spark application will take a single argument – a state code (such as CA). The
program should read the data from the devsh.accounts Hive table and save
the rows whose state column value matches the specified state code. Write the
results to /devsh_loudacre/accounts_by_state/state-code (such as
accounts_by_state/CA).

Depending on which programming language you are using, follow the appropriate set of
instructions below to write a Spark program.

Important: This exercise depends on ***Insert previous exercise title here (with link?)*** . If you did not complete that exercise, run the course catch-up script and advance to the current exercise:

$ $DEVSH/scripts/catchup.sh

Editing Scala and Python Files

You may use any text editor you wish to work on your application
code. If you do not have an editor preference, you may wish to
use Pluma, which includes language-specific support for Scala and
Python.
You can start Pluma on your remote desktop using the editor icon
on the remote desktop menu bar.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Lab

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Write and Run a Spark Application in Scala

A Maven project to get you started has been provided in the exercise directory: `/home/devuser/bin/devsh/exercises/spark-application/accounts-by-state_project/`.

The first time you build a Scala Spark application in your environment, Maven must first download the Spark libraries from the Maven central repository. This can take several minutes, so before starting work on the exercise steps, compile the exercise project following the steps below. (Maven only needs to download the libraries the first time. It caches the libraries locally, and uses the cache for subsequent builds.)

msg.data:
Write and Run a Spark Application in Scala

A Maven project to get you started has been provided in the exercise directory:
/home/devuser/bin/devsh/exercises/spark-application/accounts-by-state_project/.

The first time you build a Scala Spark application in your environment, Maven must first download the Spark libraries from the Maven central repository. This can take several minutes, so before starting work on the exercise steps, compile the exercise project following the steps below. (Maven only needs to download the libraries the first time. It caches the libraries locally, and uses the cache for subsequent builds.)

paragraphs.title: 1 - Change to the project directory
paragraphs.text:
%sh
cd /home/devuser/bin/devsh/exercises/spark-application/accounts-by-state_project/
ls

msg.data:
bonus
solution
stubs

paragraphs.title: 2 - Build the exercise project using Maven
paragraphs.text:
%md
Build the exercise project.
Maven will begin to download the required Spark libraries. Next time you build the project, Maven will used the libraries in its local cache. While Maven downloads the libraries, continue with the exercise steps below.

%sh
mvn package

msg.data: bash: mvn: command not found
ExitValue: 127

paragraphs.title: 3 - Edit the AccountsByState class
paragraphs.text:
%md
Edit the Scala class defined in stubs package in `src/main/scala/stubs/AccountsByState.scala`.

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create a SparkSession object using the following code:
paragraphs.text:
%md
```
val spark = Sparksession.builder.getOrCreate()
```

paragraphs.title: 5 - Reduce distracting output
paragraphs.text:
%md
Optional: Change the application log level from `INFO` (the default) to `WARN` to reduce distracting output.

```
spark.sparkContext.setLogLevel("WARN")
```

paragraphs.title: 6 - Load the accounts table and select accounts where the state matches the argument provided
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the body of the program, load the `accounts` Hive table into a DataFrame. Select accounts where the state column value matches the string provided as the first argument to the application. Save the results to a Parquet file called `/user/zeppelin/accounts_by_state/`*state-code* (where *state-code* is a string such as CA). Use overwrite mode when saving the file so that you can re-run the application without needing to delete the save directory.

paragraphs.title: 7 - Stopping the Spark session
paragraphs.text:
%md
At the end of the application, be sure to stop the Spark session:

```
spark.stop
```

paragraphs.title: 8 - Run Maven locally to cache Spark libraries
paragraphs.text:
%md
Return to the terminal in which you ran Maven earlier in order to cache Spark libraries locally.
If the Maven command is still running, wait for it to finish. When it finishes, rebuild the project, this time including the code you added above. This time, the Maven command should take much less time.

If the build is successful, Maven will generate a JAR file called accounts-bystate-1.0.jar in the target directory.

%sh
mvn package

paragraphs.title: 9 - If you have a Spark shell running in any terminal, exit the shell before running your application
10 - Run your application
paragraphs.text:
%md
Run the program in the compiled JAR file, passing the state code to select.
For example, to select accounts in California, use the following command:

    $ spark-submit --class stubs.AccountsByState target/accounts-by-state-1.0.jar CA

**Note:** To run the solution application, use `--class solution.AccountsByState`.

msg.data:
In a terminal window, change to the exercise working
directory, then run the program, passing the state code to select. For example, to
select accounts in California, use the following command:

$ cd $DEVSH/exercises/spark-application/
$ spark-submit python-stubs/accounts-by-state.py CA

Note: To run the solution application, use python-solution/accounts-bystate.py.

paragraphs.text:
%sh
spark-submit --class stubs.AccountsByState target/accounts-by-state-1.0.jar CA

# Solution
#spark-submit --class solution.AccountsByState target/accounts-by-state-1.0.jar CA

msg.data:
accounts-by-state_project
python-bonus
python-solution
python-stubs
run-pyspark.sh
run-scala.sh

paragraphs.title: 11 - Verify the data was saved correctly and use parquet-tools to verify the contents
paragraphs.text:
%md
After the program completes, confirm the files were saved, then use `parquet-tools` to verify that the file contents are correct.
%sh

%md
### View the Spark Application UI
In the previous section, you ran a Python Spark application using `spark-submit`. Now view that application's Spark UI (or history server UI if the application is complete).

msg.data:
View the Spark Application UI

In the previous section, you ran a Python Spark application using spark-submit. Now view that application's Spark UI (or history server UI if the application is complete).

paragraphs.title: 12 - Visit the YARN Resource Manager UI
paragraphs.text:
%md
Open the web browser on your remote desktop and visit the YARN Resource Manager UI.

To view the Spark Application UI if your application is still running, select the **ApplicationMaster** link. To view the History Service UI if your application has completed, select the **History** link.

msg.data:
Open Firefox on your remote desktop and visit the YARN Resource Manager
UI using the provided YARN RM bookmark (or go to URI http://localhost:8088/).

To view the Spark Application UI if your application is still running, select the
ApplicationMaster link. To view the History Service UI if your application has
completed, select the History link.

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Set Configuration Options Using Submit Script Flags

msg.data: Set Configuration Options Using Submit Script Flags

paragraphs.title: 13 - Specify an Application name
paragraphs.text:
%md
Change to the correct directory (if necessary) and re-run the program from the previous section, this time specifying an application name. For example:

msg.data:
Change to the correct directory (if necessary) and re-run the Python or Scala
program you wrote in the previous section, this time specifying an application
name. For example:

$ spark-submit --name "Accounts by State 1" python-stubs/accounts-by-state.py CA

$ spark-submit --name "Accounts by State 1" --class stubs.AccountsByState target/accounts-by-state-1.0.jar CA

paragraphs.text:
%sh
spark-submit --name "Accounts by State 1" --class stubs.AccountsByState target/accounts-by-state-1.0.jar CA

paragraphs.title: 14 - Use YARN UI to confirm that the application name was set correctly
paragraphs.text:
%md
Go back to the YARN RM UI in your browser, and confirm that the application name was set correctly in the list of applications.

paragraphs.title: 15 - Use YARN UI to review the properties of the application
paragraphs.text:
%md
Follow the **ApplicationMaster** or **History** link. View the **Environment** tab. Take note of the `spark.*` properties such as `master` and `app.name`.

paragraphs.title: 16 - Using the conf option
paragraphs.text:
%md
You can set most of the common application properties using submit script flags such as name, but for others you need to use conf. Use conf to set the spark.default.parallelism property, which controls how many partitions result after a "wide" RDD operation like reduceByKey.

msg.data:
You can set most of the common application properties using submit script
flags such as name, but for others you need to use conf. Use conf to set the
spark.default.parallelism property, which controls how many partitions
result after a “wide” RDD operation like reduceByKey.

$ spark-submit --name "Accounts by State 2" \
--conf spark.default.parallelism=4 \
python-stubs/accounts-by-state.py CA

$ spark-submit --name "Accounts by State 2" \
--conf spark.default.parallelism=4 \
--class stubs.AccountsByState \
target/accounts-by-state-1.0.jar CA

paragraphs.text:
%sh
spark-submit --name "Accounts by State 2" \
    --conf spark.default.parallelism=4 \
    --class stubs.AccountsByState \
    target/accounts-by-state-1.0.jar CA

paragraphs.title: 17 - Use YARN UI to confirm that the parallelism property is set correctly
paragraphs.text:
%md
View the application history for this application to confirm that the `spark.default.parallelism` property was set correctly. (You will need to view the YARN RM UI again to view the correct application's history.)

%md
### *Optional:* Review Property Setting Overrides

msg.data: Optional: Review Property Setting Overrides

paragraphs.title: 18 - Display Application Property values
paragraphs.text:
%md
Rerun the previous submit command with the verbose option. This will display
your application property default and override values.

msg.data:
Rerun the previous submit command with the verbose option. This will display
your application property default and override values.

$ spark-submit --verbose --name "Accounts by State 3" \
--conf spark.default.parallelism=4 \
python-stubs/accounts-by-state.py CA

$ spark-submit --verbose --name "Accounts by State 3" \
--conf spark.default.parallelism=4 \
--class stubs.AccountsByState \
target/accounts-by-state-1.0.jar CA

paragraphs.text:
%sh
spark-submit --verbose --name "Accounts by State 3" \
    --conf spark.default.parallelism=4 \
    --class stubs.AccountsByState \
    target/accounts-by-state-1.0.jar CA

paragraphs.title: 19 - Examine the properties
paragraphs.text:
%md
Examine the extra output displayed when the application starts up.

**a.** The first section starts with `Using properties file`, and shows the
file name and the default property settings the application loaded from that
properties file.

- What is the system properties file?

- What properties are being set in the file?

**b.** The second section starts with Parsed arguments. This lists the arguments
- that is, the flags and settings - you set when running the submit script
(except for `conf`). Submit script flags that you did not pass use their default
values, if defined by the script, or are shown as `null`.

- Does the list correctly include the value you set with `--name`?

- Which arguments (flags) have defaults set in the script and which do not?

**c.** Scroll down to the section that starts with `System properties`. This list
shows *all* the properties set - those loaded from the system properties file,
those you set using submit script arguments, and those you set using the conf
flag.

- Is `spark.default.parallelism` included and set correctly?

msg.data:
Examine the extra output displayed when the application starts up.

a. The first section starts with Using properties file, and shows the
file name and the default property settings the application loaded from that
properties file.

  • What is the system properties file?

  • What properties are being set in the file?

b. The second section starts with Parsed arguments. This lists the arguments

  • that is, the flags and settings - you set when running the submit script
    (except for conf). Submit script flags that you did not pass use their default
    values, if defined by the script, or are shown as null.

  • Does the list correctly include the value you set with --name?

  • Which arguments (flags) have defaults set in the script and which do not?

c. Scroll down to the section that starts with System properties. This list
shows all the properties set - those loaded from the system properties file,
those you set using submit script arguments, and those you set using the conf
flag.

  • Is spark.default.parallelism included and set correctly?

If you have more time, attempt the following extra bonus steps:

paragraphs.title: 1 - Set the application name
paragraphs.text:
%md
Using the builder function `appName` will set the application name.

paragraphs.title: 2 - Run the application again
paragraphs.text:
%md
Re-run the application without using script options to set properties.

paragraphs.title: 3 - Use the YARN UI to confirm the application name was correctly set
paragraphs.text:
%md
View the YARN UI to confirm that the application name was correctly set.

%md
You can find the solution in the `bonus` package in the exercise project.

msg.data:
You can find the Python bonus solution in $DEVSH/exercises/sparkapplication/python-bonus.
The Scala solution is in the bonus package in the exercise project.

This section will show you how to correctly edit the stub file and the correct commands for the exercise to run completely and without errors. The solution file is provided for comparison, there is no need to edit it.

val spark = Sparksession.builder.getOrCreate()

paragraphs.title: 5 - Reduce distracting output

Optional: Change the application log level from `INFO` (the default) to `WARN` to reduce distracting output.

spark.sparkContext.setLogLevel("WARN")

paragraphs.title: 6 - Load the accounts table and select accounts where the state matches the argument provided
paragraphs.text:
%md
In the body of the program, load the `accounts` Hive table into a DataFrame. Select accounts where the state column value matches the string provided as the first argument to the application. Save the results to a Parquet file called `/user/zeppelin/accounts_by_state/`*state-code* (where *state-code* is a string such as CA). Use overwrite mode when saving the file so that you can re-run the application without needing to delete the save directory.

paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
  3. Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs - official Spark documentation.
  4. Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs - official Zeppelin documentation.
